encodingDesc.p: This document is a simplified "true-to-text" XML version of The Spanish Curate based on Pennsylvania State University's annotated copy of the 1647 Beaumont & Fletcher first folio. Major textual elements and attributes have been captured based on how they appear in the folio. Whenever possible, editorial interventions have been minimalized or avoided entirely. This document is meant to serve as a pedagogical tool by which students of Early Modern literature can learn to construct edited XML versions of the play.

projectDesc.p: The Digital Beaumont & Fletcher (1647) is a collaborative editorial project aimed at making many of the rarely edited—and, as a result, rarely taught—plays in the “Beaumont & Fletcher” canon accessible to student readers and freely available online for classroom use. This project was inspired by the distinctive copy of Comedies and Tragedies Written by Francis Beavmont And Iohn Fletcher Gentlemen (1647) held by Penn State University's Eberly Family Special Collections Library. In addition to preserving evidence of ownership dating to as early as 1703, Penn State's copy of this printed play collection also includes three plays with handwritten marginalia, suggesting that the book might have been used to facilitate performance in the late seventeenth century. This project is also motivated by a desire to make the texts and other features of this book more widely known and readable. As a first step, the whole volume has now been fully digitized, thanks to the department of Preservation, Conservation, and Digitization at Penn State Libraries.

handNote.p: This edition of The Spanish Curate contains the marginal notes found in the Penn State Libraries' copy of the 1647 folio. These manuscript notes are particually attentive to the performance of the play, and prepare actors for entrances and emphasize stage directions throughout the text. These manuscript notes have been added to the text without modernization spelling of puncuation.

Not to be spent in words. Here no more wooing:
The open air's an enemy to lovers.
Do as I tell ye.

lg.l: I'll do anything.Cross-hatched lines.
I am so over-joyed: I'll fly to serve ye.
Take your joy moderately, as it is ministered,
And as the cause invites. That man's a foolbartolus be ready
That at the sight o'th'bond dances and leaps.
Then is the true joy: when the money comes.
You cannot now deny me.
Nay, you know not;
Women have crotchets and strange fits crotchets and strange fits: whimsical thoughts and struggles.
You shall not.
Hold ye to that and swear it confidently,
Then I shall make a scruple scruple: hesitation to deny ye.
'Pray ye, let's step in and see a friend of mine.
The weather's sharp: we'll stay but half an hour;
We may be missed else. A private fine house 'tis, sir,
And we may find many good welcomes.
Do, Lady;
Do, happy Lady.
All your mind's of doing;
You must be modester.
I will be anything.—
Open the doors and give me room to chafe in; [knocks]
Mine owne room and my liberty: why maid there,

lg.l: Open, I say, and do not anger me:
I am subject to much fury. When, ye dish-clout dish-clout: dishcloth?
When do ye come? Asleepe, ye lazy hell-hound?
Nothing intended but your ease and eating?
Nobody here? Why wife, why wife? Why jewel?
No tongue to answer me? 'Prithee, (good pupil),
Dispense a little with thy careful study,
And step to th'door, and let me in. Nor he neither?
Ha! Not at's study? Nor asleep? Nor nobody? [knocks]
I'll make ye hear: the house of ignorance,
No sound inhabitants here: I have a key yet
That commands all. I fear I am metamorphosed.Cross-hatched lines.

div.stage: [Bartolus exits into house as Lopez, Arsenio, Milanes, and Diego enter]

lg.l: He keeps his fury still and may do mischief.
He shall be hanged first; we'll be sticklers sticklers: moderators there, boys.
The hundred thousand dreams now that possess him:
Of jealousy, and of revenge, and frailty.
Of drawing bills against us and petitions.
And casting what his credit shall recover.
Let him cast till his maw maw: previously eaten food. Milanes things Bartolus may throw up. came up: we care not.
You shall be still secured.
We'll pay him home then. A great noise within.
Hark what a noise he keeps within?
Certain
Has set his chimneys o'fire, or the devil roars there.
The codexes o'th'law codexes o'th'law: systems of law are broke loose, gentlemen.
He's fighting sure.
I'll tell ye that immediately—
Or doing some strange out-rage on himself.
Hang him; he dares not be so valiant.
There's nobody at home and he chases like a lion
And stinks stinks: acts offensively withall.
Nobody?
Not a creature.
Nothing within but he and his Law-tempest law-tempest: anger;
The ladles, dishes, kettles, how they fly all?
And how the glasses through the rooms?

div.stage: Enter Bartolus [but does not see the group on stage].

lg.l: My friends sure
Has got her out and now he has made an end on't.
See where the sea comes? How it foams and brussels?
The great leviathan leviathan: sea monster o'th'law, how it tumbles?
Made every way an ass? Abused on all sides
And from all quarters? People come to laugh at me?
Rise like a comet to be wondered at?
A horrid comet, for boy's tongues and ballads boy's tongues and ballads: songs and performances?
I will run from my wits.
Do, do,(good lawyer),
And from thy money too, then thou wilt be quiet.
Here she comes home: now mark the salutations.
How like an ass my friend goes?
She has pulled his ears down pulled his ears down: dragged him.
Now, what sweet voyage to what garden, Lady?
Or to what cousin's house?
Is this my welcome?
I cannot go to church, but thus I am scandalled.
Use no devotion for my soul, but gentlemen—
To church?
Yes, and ye keep sweet youths to wait upon me,
Sweet, bred-up youths, to be a credit to me.
There's your delight again, pray take him to ye;
He never comes near me more to debase me.
How's this? How's this? Good wife, how has he wronged ye?
I am faine to drive him like a sheep before me
I blush to think how people fleer fleer: shun, and scorned me.
Others have handsome men, that know behaviour,
Place, and observance: this silly thing knows nothing,
Cannot tell ten. Let every rascal justle me,
And still I pushed him on as he had been coming.
Ha! Did ye push him on? Is he so stupid?
When others were attentive to the priest,
Good devout gentleman, then fell he fast,
Fast, sound asleep. Then first began the bag-pipes
The several stops on's nose, made a rare music,
A rare and loud, and those played many an anthem
Put out of that, he fell straight into dreaming Then first...into dreaming: Amaranta recalls the emberassment of having Leandro fall asleep and snore loudly during a church service..
As cunning as she is sweet; I like this carriage carriage: conduct.
What did he then?
Why then he talked in his sleep, too.
Nay, I'll divulge your moral virtues, (sheep's-face),
And talked aloud, that every ear was fixed to him.
Did not I suffer, (do you think), in this time?
Talk of your bawling law bawling law: shouting law, of appellationsappellations: appeals,
Of declarations, and excommunications;
Warrants, the executions: and such devils
That drove all the gentlemen out o'th'Church, by hurries
With execrable oaths execrable oaths: awful promises they would never come there again.
Thus am I served and manned manned: accompanied.
I pray ye forgive me.
I must confess I am not fit to wait upon ye:
Alas, I was brought up—
To be an ass,
A lawyer's ass: to carry books and buckrams.
But what did you at church?
At church, did ye ask her?
Do you hear, gentlemen, do you mark the question?
Because you are half an heretic yourself, sir;
Would ye breed her too? This shall to the Inquisition,
A pious gentlewoman, reproved for praying?
I'll see this filed, and you shall hear further, sir.
Ye have an ill heart.
It shall be found out, gentlemen.
There be those youths will search it.
You are warm, signiour.

Enough to hang him, do not doubt.
Nay, certain,
I do believe has rather no religion.
That must be known too, because she goes to Church, sir?

Let him go on, sir,
His wealth will build a nunnery; a fair one.
And this good Lady, when he is hanged and rotten,
May there be abbess abbess: Mother Superior of a nunnery..
You are cozend, honest gentlemen.
I do not forbid the use but the form: mark me.
Form? What do ye make of form?
They will undo me.
Swear, as I oft have done, and so betray me.
I must make fair way and hereafter. Wife,
You are welcome home, and henceforth take your pleasure.
Go, when ye shall think fit; I will not hinder ye.
My eyes are open now, and I see my error.
My shame, as great as that, but I must hide it.
The whole conveyance now I smell, but basta,
Another time must serve. You see us friends, now
Heartily friends, and no more chiding, (gentlemen).
I have been too foolish, I confess. No more words,
No more, (sweet wife).
You know my easy nature.
Go, get ye in. [Amaranta exits into house] you see she has been angry:
Forebeare her fight a while and time will pacify,
And learne to be more bold.
I would I could,
I will do all I am able.

We will not part, but friends of all hands.
Well said.
Now ye are reasonable, we can look on ye.
Ye have jerked jerked: mocked me: but for all that I forgive ye
Forgive ye heartily, and do invite ye
Tomorrow to a breakfast I make but seldom.
But now we will be merry.
Now ye are friendly,
Your doggedness and nigardize doggedness and nigardize: cruelty and stinginess flung from ye,

Give me your hands, all;
You shall be welcome heartily.
We will be,

Farewell, good bountiful Bartolus, 'tis a brave wench
A sudden witty theif, and worth all service.
Go we'll all go, and crucify the lawyer.

Well, Leandro,
Thou hast had a strange voyage, but I hope
Thou rid'st now in safe harbour.
Let's go drink, friends,
And laugh aloud at all our merry May-games.
A match, a match 'twill wet our stomachs better.
